Randomized Quantization is All You Need for Differential Privacy in Federated Learning

Yeojoon Youn
Georgia Institute of Technology
yjyoun92@gatech.edu
&Zihao Hu
Georgia Institute of Technology
zihaohu@gatech.edu
&Juba Ziani

Abstract

Federated learning (FL) is a common and practical framework for learning a machine model in a decentralized fashion. A primary motivation behind this decentralized approach is data privacy, ensuring that the learner never sees the data of each local source itself. Federated learning then comes with two majors challenges: one is handling potentially complex model updates between a server and a large number of data sources; the other is that de-centralization may, in fact, be insufficient for privacy, as the local updates themselves can reveal information about the sources’ data. To address these issues, we consider an approach to federated learning that combines quantization and differential privacy. Absent privacy, Federated Learning often relies on quantization to reduce communication complexity. We build upon this approach and develop a new algorithm called the Randomized Quantization Mechanism (RQM), which obtains privacy through a two-levels of randomization. More precisely, we randomly sub-sample feasible quantization levels, then employ a randomized rounding procedure using these sub-sampled discrete levels. We are able to establish that our results preserve “Renyi differential privacy” (Renyi DP). We empirically study the performance of our algorithm and demonstrate that compared to previous work it yields improved privacy-accuracy trade-offs for DP federated learning. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first study that solely relies on randomized quantization without incorporating explicit discrete noise to achieve Renyi DP guarantees in Federated Learning systems.

1 Introduction

Federated Learning (FL) is an innovative approach to training on massive datasets, utilizing a multitude of devices like smartphones and IoT devices, each containing locally stored, privacy-sensitive data. At a basic level, privacy is maintained by storing local data on each end-user device without sharing it with the server. However, in some cases, device or local device data can be partially reconstructed from computed gradients (Zhu et al.,, 2019). This potential data leakage from gradients can be addressed through the use of privacy-preserving techniques. Equally important in the context of FL is communication efficiency. Given the extensive communication demands placed on many edge computing devices and the constraints of limited bandwidth, it is imperative to devise a training scheme that not only preserves privacy but also aligns with the requirements of efficient communication within FL systems. What is perhaps surprising, however, is that these two objectives are not necessarily in tension and can even be aligned! One way to improve communication overhead is to reduce bit complexity through stochastic rounding schemes, but we show that these randomization procedures, if designed carefully, provide additional benefits to data privacy.

Past studies, such as the work of Agarwal et al., (2018); Kairouz et al., (2021); Agarwal et al., (2021), have sought to tackle this issue by employing various forms of discrete additive DP noise in conjunction with quantization. This is because the application of continuous noise post-quantization would effectively render the noise update continuous, negating any benefits to communication efficiency. However, when these discrete additive noise methods are coupled with secure aggregation protocols (Bonawitz et al.,, 2017), aimed at preventing a server from inspecting individual local device updates, they encounter a challenge of biased estimation due to gradient clipping. To solve this, Chen et al., (2022) introduce the Poisson Binomial Mechanism (PBM), bypassing the use of additive noise and instead directly mapping continuous inputs to discrete values in an unbiased fashion.

Losses in accuracy compared to noise-free gradient updates that do not protect privacy in the strong sense afforded by differential privacy are essentially unavoidable. The addition of a privacy requirement inevitably constraints the learner’s problem, and privacy must be traded-off with accuracy. Yet, the solution provided by Chen et al., (2022), while providing good performance, may still enjoy sub-optimal privacy-accuracy trade-offs. Can we develop new mechanisms with improved privacy-accuracy trade-off compared to the mechanism of Chen et al., (2022)?

Our starting point to address this question is to note that much research focusing on quantization in federated learning for the sake of communication complexity absent privacy (Alistarh et al.,, 2017; Reisizadeh et al.,, 2020; Haddadpour et al.,, 2021; Youn et al.,, 2022) reveal that performance degradation from quantization alone is somewhat minimal. Furthermore, quantization itself inherently reduces the amount of information encoded about the original input. While quantization in itself is insufficient for privacy, we posit that a two-stage approach, selecting a randomized quantization scheme followed by randomized rounding, can provide a viable approach to obtaining low communication complexity, formal differential privacy guarantees, while still enjoying good performance. Thus:

  • Can we harness randomization in quantization schemes to further improve privacy-accuracy trade-offs in differentially private federated learning?

To address this question, we introduce what we call the Randomized Quantization Mechanism, or RQM for short. RQM achieves privacy entirely through randomly sub-sampling quantization levels followed by a (randomized) rounding procedure to a close-by quantization level.

Summary of contributions

As mentioned above, our paper studies mechanisms for releasing gradients while satisfying Renyi differential privacy, and how our proposed mechanisms can be integrated in standard federated learning frameworks.

  • •

    In Section 5, we introduce our Randomized Quantization Mechanism that maps gradients to a randomized discrete grid in a way that preserves Renyi differential privacy.

  • •

    In Section 5.3, we provide theoretical evidence that our proposed Randomized Quantization Mechanism exhibits α−limit-from𝛼\alpha-Renyi differential privacy guarantees “locally”, at the level of each single end-user device. Our theoretical guarantees hold for α→+∞→𝛼\alpha\to+\infty, implying in particular that they hold not just for Renyi but also for traditional (ϵ,0)italic-ϵ0(\epsilon,0)-differential privacy.

  • •

    In Section 6, we provide experiments that highlight the performance of our mechanism. In particular, we show that RQM outperforms the state-of-the-art Poisson Binomial Mechanism (PBM) introduced by Chen et al., (2022) in two ways. First, we show that for any given α𝛼\alpha, RQM provides lower Renyi divergence hence better Renyi DP guarantees than the work of Chen et al., (2022). Second, we also show that when RQM is plugged in the standard differentially private federated learning framework, it leads to high model accuracy when compared to that demonstrated by Chen et al., (2022).

2 Related work

Both communication complexity and privacy concerns have been driving forces behind the development of Federated Learning. Federated optimization often uses two types of privacy-preserving techniques hand-in-hand. One is secure multi-party computation, which protects the communication between local devices and the learner, preventing an attacker from intercepting messages sent between them (Bell et al.,, 2020; Bonawitz et al.,, 2017). One is information-theoretic privacy guarantees such as differential privacy (Dwork et al.,, 2014) that prevent inference of any given single local device’s data from observed summary outputs (such as local gradient updates or the learner’s model itself). For example, McMahan et al., 2017b and Geyer et al., (2017) add a calibrated amount of Gaussian noise to the average of clipped local device updates based on the FedAvg (McMahan et al., 2017a, ) algorithm.

In this paper, we focus on providing robust Renyi differential privacy guarantees in federated optimization while maintaining high communication efficiency and good accuracy. Previous methods have often used an approach based on quantization followed by the addition of discrete noise to achieve both differential privacy guarantees and low communication efficiency. Agarwal et al., (2018) introduces the first communication-efficient federated optimization algorithm with differential privacy by incorporating quantization with the binomial mechanism. Kairouz et al., (2021) and Agarwal et al., (2021) employ discrete Gaussian and Skellam mechanisms, respectively, in conjunction with quantization and secure aggregation for enhanced privacy. However, the above methods lead to biased estimation due to the necessity of modular clipping. To address this issue, Chen et al., (2022) and Chaudhuri et al., (2022) propose unbiased mechanisms with improved privacy-accuracy trade-offs. Chen et al., (2022) encodes local devices’ gradients into a parameter of the binomial distribution, allowing their mechanism to generate a sample from this distribution without the need for additive discrete noise. In contrast, rather than using known privacy mechanisms, Chaudhuri et al., (2022) introduces the Minimum Variance Unbiased mechanism (MVU) to enhance the privacy-utility trade-off by solving an optimization problem designed to minimize the output variance of the mechanism while adhering to local differential privacy and unbiasedness constraints. Despite their progress in improving the privacy-utility trade-off, these methods do not fully exploit the privacy advantages offered by randomized quantization itself.

Our research is not the first to leverage compression techniques to achieve both communication efficiency and provable privacy benefits without incorporating additive discrete noise (Li et al.,, 2019; Gandikota et al.,, 2021). Li et al., (2019) assume a Gaussian input vector distribution for their sketching algorithms to ensure differential privacy guarantees, which might not be strictly necessary. Gandikota et al., (2021) ultimately first quantize the gradients updates, then randomize the quantized gradients via differential private mechanisms such as randomized response or Rappor (Erlingsson et al.,, 2014). However, and to the best of our knowledge, our Randomized Quantization Mechanism is the first investigation that exclusively utilizes randomization of the quantization itself to attain improved Renyi DP guarantees within Federated Learning frameworks.

3 Preliminaries

3.1 Differential privacy

Given that we employ the concept of differential privacy to demonstrate the privacy guarantees of our Randomized Quantization Mechanism, we first present the original definition of differential privacy.

Definition 3.1.

((Approximate) Differential Privacy (Dwork et al.,, 2006)) For ϵ,δ≥0italic-ϵ𝛿0\epsilon,\delta\geq 0, a randomized mechanism ℳ:𝒟→ℛ:ℳ→𝒟ℛ\mathcal{M}:\mathcal{D}\rightarrow\mathcal{R} satisfies (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-differential privacy if for any neighbor dataset D,D′∈𝒟𝐷superscript𝐷′𝒟D,D^{\prime}\in\mathcal{D} differing by the addition or removal of a single user’s records, it holds that

Pr​(ℳ​(D)∈E)≤eϵ⋅Pr​(ℳ​(D′)∈E)+δPrℳ𝐷𝐸⋅superscript𝑒italic-ϵPrℳsuperscript𝐷′𝐸𝛿\displaystyle\textrm{Pr}(\mathcal{M}(D)\in E)\leq e^{\epsilon}\cdot\textrm{Pr}(\mathcal{M}(D^{\prime})\in E)+\delta

for all events E⊂ℛ𝐸ℛE\subset\mathcal{R}.

In this paper, we also consider a variant of standard differential privacy called Renyi Differential Privacy (or Renyi DP), introduced in the seminal work of Mironov, (2017). We develop mechanisms that guarantee Renyi DP and by extension traditional DP. The use of Renyi DP allows for tight privacy accounting throughout the training iterations. Renyi differential privacy relies on first understanding the notion of Renyi divergence:

Definition 3.2.

(Renyi Divergence (Rényi,, 1961)) Let P𝑃P and Q𝑄Q be probability distributions defined over ℛℛ\mathcal{R}. The Renyi divergence of order α>1𝛼1\alpha>1 is defined as

Dα(P||Q):=1α−1log𝔼x∼Q[(P​(x)Q​(x))α].\displaystyle D_{\alpha}(P||Q):=\frac{1}{\alpha-1}\log\mathbb{E}_{x\sim Q}\Big{[}\Big{(}\frac{P(x)}{Q(x)}\Big{)}^{\alpha}\Big{]}.

Then, Renyi differential privacy is defined as follows:

Definition 3.3.

(Renyi Differential Privacy (Mironov,, 2017)) A randomized mechanism ℳ:𝒟→ℛ:ℳ→𝒟ℛ\mathcal{M}:\mathcal{D}\rightarrow\mathcal{R} satisfies (α,ϵ)𝛼italic-ϵ(\alpha,\epsilon)-Renyi differential privacy if for any neighbor dataset D,D′∈𝒟𝐷superscript𝐷′𝒟D,D^{\prime}\in\mathcal{D} it holds that

Dα(Pℳ​(D)||Pℳ​(D′))≤ϵ.\displaystyle D_{\alpha}(P_{\mathcal{M}(D)}||P_{\mathcal{M}(D^{\prime})})\leq\epsilon. (1)

When α→∞→𝛼\alpha\to\infty, (α,ϵ)𝛼italic-ϵ(\alpha,\epsilon)-Renyi DP in fact recovers standard (ϵ,0)italic-ϵ0(\epsilon,0)-DP. However, Renyi DP provides a finer-grained definition of privacy in that its guarantees can be tailored to the specific value of α𝛼\alpha and corresponding Renyi divergence that one considers. We now state a major property of the Renyi divergence that is useful to our theoretical analysis.

Lemma 3.4.

(Monotonicity) Dαsubscript𝐷𝛼D_{\alpha} is nondecreasing in α𝛼\alpha. I.e., Dα(P||Q)≤Dα′(P||Q)D_{\alpha}(P||Q)\leq D_{\alpha^{\prime}}(P||Q) for all 1≤α≤α′≤∞1𝛼superscript𝛼′1\leq\alpha\leq\alpha^{\prime}\leq\infty.

3.2 User-level privacy

In the context of federated learning, we employ differential privacy to mask the contribution of any individual local device, making it challenging for a potential adversary to discern whether a local device’s dataset was utilized in the training process. As such, we need to extend the traditional item-level definition of differential privacy (Definition 3.1) by redefining what we mean by neighboring datasets. In this context, two datasets are considered neighboring if one dataset can be created by changing any subset of data points of a single user from the other dataset. This user-level perspective is relatively standard and is the same as the one studied by McMahan et al., 2017b and Levy et al., (2021).

Definition 3.5.

(User-level DP (Levy et al.,, 2021)) For ϵ,δ≥0italic-ϵ𝛿0\epsilon,\delta\geq 0, a randomized mechanism ℳ:𝒟→ℛ:ℳ→𝒟ℛ\mathcal{M}:\mathcal{D}\rightarrow\mathcal{R} satisfies (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-user level DP if for any neighbor dataset D,D′∈𝒟𝐷superscript𝐷′𝒟D,D^{\prime}\in\mathcal{D} satisfying duser​(D,D′)≤1subscriptduser𝐷superscript𝐷′1\text{d}_{\text{user}}(D,D^{\prime})\leq 1, it holds that

Pr​(ℳ​(D)∈E)≤eϵ⋅Pr​(ℳ​(D′)∈E)+δPrℳ𝐷𝐸⋅superscript𝑒italic-ϵPrℳsuperscript𝐷′𝐸𝛿\displaystyle\textrm{Pr}(\mathcal{M}(D)\in E)\leq e^{\epsilon}\cdot\textrm{Pr}(\mathcal{M}(D^{\prime})\in E)+\delta

for all events E⊂ℛ𝐸ℛE\subset\mathcal{R}, where dusersubscriptduser\text{d}_{\text{user}} is defined with n𝑛n users as

D=(D1,⋯,Dn), where ​Di={zi,1,⋯,zi,mi}→duser​(D,D′):=∑i=1n1​{Di≠Di′}formulae-sequence𝐷subscript𝐷1⋯subscript𝐷𝑛 where subscript𝐷𝑖subscript𝑧𝑖1⋯subscript𝑧𝑖subscript𝑚𝑖→subscriptduser𝐷superscript𝐷′assignsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛1subscript𝐷𝑖superscriptsubscript𝐷𝑖′\displaystyle D=(D_{1},\cdots,D_{n}),\textrm{ where }D_{i}=\{z_{i,1},\cdots,z_{i,m_{i}}\}\rightarrow\text{d}_{\text{user}}(D,D^{\prime}):=\sum_{i=1}^{n}1\{D_{i}\neq D_{i}^{\prime}\}

4 Model

We consider a federated learning set-up comprised of three types of entities: there are n𝑛n end-user devices, one secure aggregator called SecAgg, and one learner. The learner’s goal is to learn a machine learning model, parameterized by a f𝑓f-dimensional vector w∈ℝf𝑤superscriptℝ𝑓w\in\mathbb{R}^{f}, using the data on the devices through Stochastic Gradient Descent (SGD). However, the learner does not access the data from the devices directly, both for communication efficiency and privacy reasons. Rather, at each time step t𝑡t:

  1. 1.

    Each end-user device i𝑖i computes a clipped gradient gti∈[−c,c]fsubscriptsuperscript𝑔𝑖𝑡superscript𝑐𝑐𝑓g^{i}_{t}\in[-c,c]^{f} locally using the data on that device only. This gradient is then encoded into an integer ztisubscriptsuperscript𝑧𝑖𝑡z^{i}_{t}. This integer can be seen as the index of a discrete level in a discretization of the space of potential gradients.

  2. 2.

    The secure aggregator receives one message ztisubscriptsuperscript𝑧𝑖𝑡z^{i}_{t} from each device i𝑖i, which encodes information about the gradient gtisubscriptsuperscript𝑔𝑖𝑡g^{i}_{t} computed by i𝑖i. The aggregator aggregates them into a single message zt=∑iztisubscript𝑧𝑡subscript𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝑧𝑖𝑡z_{t}=\sum_{i}z^{i}_{t}.

  3. 3.

    The server decodes ztsubscript𝑧𝑡z_{t}, computes the corresponding gradient g^tsubscript^𝑔𝑡\hat{g}_{t}, and takes a gradient step wt+1←wt−η​g^t←subscript𝑤𝑡1subscript𝑤𝑡𝜂subscript^𝑔𝑡w_{t+1}\leftarrow w_{t}-\eta\hat{g}_{t}.

The traditional approach to federated learning releases gradients exactly; this approach is, however, i) inefficient from a communication complexity perspective and ii) vulnerable when it comes to privacy. We address i) by discretizing (or “quantizing”) the space of possible values of the gradients to a grid of size m𝑚m per coordinate of the gradient; in turn, we require only f×log⁡m𝑓𝑚f\times\log m bits to represent a single update by a single device. Regarding ii), we note that it is well-understood that releasing exact gradients can lead to privacy violations in that the secure aggregator and the learner can recover information about device i𝑖i’s dataset Disubscript𝐷𝑖D_{i} through the gradient itself. To address this issue, instead of releasing the gradient gtisubscriptsuperscript𝑔𝑖𝑡g^{i}_{t} directly, device i𝑖i releases a noisy quantization level zti=R​Q​M​(gti)subscriptsuperscript𝑧𝑖𝑡𝑅𝑄𝑀subscriptsuperscript𝑔𝑖𝑡z^{i}_{t}=RQM(g^{i}_{t}), where RQM is a Randomized Quantization Mechanism that must satisfy Renyi differential privacy. The entire setup is described formally in Algorithm 1.

What algorithm 1 describes is essentially the well-known, generic Differentially Private Stochastic Gradient Descent approach to federated learning (McMahan et al., 2017b, ). The focus and novelty of our work, however, come from the design of the private mechanism RQM itself. We propose our new mechanism in Section 5, characterize its privacy guarantees in terms of Renyi differential privacy theoretically in Section 5.3 and empirically in Section 6, and study the accuracy of the resulting model when using privately-released gradient updates to train it in Section 6.

5 The Randomized Quantization Mechanism

In this section, we introduce our main building block for privacy in federated learning. This building block provides a mechanism for privately releasing a scalar aggregate statistic of a single user’s data in the form of a new algorithm called the Randomized Quantization Mechanism (RQM). We remark that when dealing with f𝑓f-dimensional vectors instead, we apply our Randomized Quantization Mechanism independently to each vector coordinate.

We first formally present our RQM mechanism, outlined in Algorithm 2. Since our mechanism relies on a discrete probability distribution to choose the quantization, we show how this probability distribution over the quantizations translates into a probability distribution over outcomes of our mechanism on any given input x𝑥x; this distribution over outcomes is crucial to characterize the level of privacy obtained by our mechanism. Finally, we theoretically analyze the Renyi differential privacy guarantees of RQM by using this distribution over outcomes.

5.1 Randomized Quantization Mechanism

In this section, we assume that each user outputs a continuous scalar input x𝑥x computed from their data; this can be viewed as the simplest case of local updates.

Our RQM algorithm is then comprised of three key components: (1) enlarging the output range beyond the input range and setting up evenly spaced quantization bins, (2) sub-sampling realized quantization levels, and (3) performing a randomized rounding procedure on the sub-sampled (and only those) discrete levels to map a value x𝑥x to a quantization level. Each of these steps is crucial in ensuring the Renyi DP guarantees of the RQM, as we describe below. Formally, in each step, we perform the following operations:

  1. 1.

    We establish the output range of our mechanism by first augmenting the size of the input range. We do so by adding ΔΔ\Delta to the upper bound c𝑐c and subtracting ΔΔ\Delta from the lower bound −c𝑐-c on the input data. This augmentation of the range is necessary for privacy: if we use the same range for the output, the quantization output for the maximum input (x=c𝑥𝑐x=c) would subsequently always be c𝑐c subsequently, leaking a lot of information about x𝑥x. After this, we establish m𝑚m initial, evenly spaced quantization levels (B​(0),B​(1),⋯,B​(m−1)𝐵0𝐵1⋯𝐵𝑚1B(0),B(1),\cdots,B(m-1)) within this output range, which will be potential outputs of our mechanism.

  2. 2.

    Instead of using the entire set of quantization levels from step (1), we randomly sub-sample feasible quantization levels. We do so by including each discrete level for quantization with a carefully chosen probability q𝑞q. The randomization of the quantization levels is necessary for privacy; otherwise, a value of x𝑥x would always map to the fixed set of two quantization levels deterministically. This immediately breaks differential privacy.

  3. 3.

    We perform quantization on the sub-sampled discrete levels (and these sub-sampled levels only), achieving both robust privacy and unbiased estimation. We identify the quantization bin that houses the input x𝑥x and perform randomized rounding on x𝑥x within this interval. The specific probabilities employed for randomized rounding can be reviewed in Algorithm 2.

The randomized quantization and rounding procedures described above are also illustrated later on in Figure 1(a).

5.1.1 Flexibility of RQM hyperparameters

The hyperparameters within our RQM algorithm offer enhanced flexibility, allowing for a more nuanced hyperparameter optimization when compared to PBM. RQM has in fact three hyperparameters Δ,q,mΔ𝑞𝑚\Delta,q,m, while PBM has two hyperparameters θ,m𝜃𝑚\theta,m (See Algorithm 2 in Chen et al., (2022)). At a fixed number of discrete levels m𝑚m, i.e. at a fixed level of communication complexity, this allows us to search over a bigger space of output distributions of quantization levels than Chen et al., (2022) through the choice of (q,Δ)𝑞Δ(q,\Delta).In Section 6.2, we show that this leads to RQM achieving better privacy-accuracy trade-offs than PBM.

5.2 Resulting discrete distribution of outcomes

Given an input x𝑥x and parameters m,q,Δ𝑚𝑞Δm,q,\Delta, we can compute the discrete probability distribution of outputs Q​(x)𝑄𝑥Q(x) of RQM over the set of potential quantization levels B​(0),B​(1),⋯​B​(m−1)𝐵0𝐵1⋯𝐵𝑚1{B(0),B(1),\cdots B(m-1)}. This discrete probability distribution is given in Lemma 5.1:

Lemma 5.1.

Let m∈ℕ𝑚ℕm\in\mathbb{N}, and q∈(0,1)𝑞01q\in(0,1) be parameters of Randomized Quantization Mechanism Q𝑄Q. Define evenly spaced m𝑚m quantization levels B​(0),⋯,B​(m−1)𝐵0⋯𝐵𝑚1B(0),\cdots,B(m-1) as in Algorithm 2. Let j𝑗j be the unique integer such that x∈[B​(j),B​(j+1))𝑥𝐵𝑗𝐵𝑗1x\in[B(j),B(j+1)). The full proof of Lemma 5.1 is provided in Appx. B.1. Equation (5.1) exhibits different cases for Pr​(Q​(x)=i)Pr𝑄𝑥𝑖\text{Pr}(Q(x)=i). These cases depend on i) how the i𝑖i-th quantization level compares to j𝑗j, where j𝑗j is defined to be such that x∈[B​(j),B​(j+1))𝑥𝐵𝑗𝐵𝑗1x\in[B(j),B(j+1)) and ii) on the two special cases i=0𝑖0i=0 or i=m−1𝑖𝑚1i=m-1. The probabilities corresponding to these two extreme values of i𝑖i differ from the rest in that we always incorporate the 00-th and (m−1𝑚1m-1)-th discrete level, which influences our probability calculations.

Figures 1(a) and 1(b) provide some insights into how to derive the distribution of outputs and gives some intuition for Lemma 5.1. In Figure 1(a), the solid lines corresponding to the (0,3,4,7,9,10,14,15034791014150,3,4,7,9,10,14,15)-th discrete levels have been selected for quantization, while the dotted lines (1,2,5,6,8,11,12,13125681112131,2,5,6,8,11,12,13)-th discrete levels have been thrown away. To have Q​(x)=10𝑄𝑥10Q(x)=10, the 101010-th discrete level must always be chosen while the 111111-th discrete level must not be chosen by the sub-sampling step of our algorithm; the probability of this happening is q​(1−q)𝑞1𝑞q(1-q). The probability of the next quantization level bigger than x𝑥x being the 141414-th level, as shown in Figure 1(a), is similarly given by q​(1−q)2𝑞superscript1𝑞2q(1-q)^{2} (levels 121212 and 131313 must not be sub-sampled, but 141414 must be). Then, the likelihood of x𝑥x transitioning to the 101010-th discrete level due to randomized rounding between the 101010-th and 141414-th levels is B​(14)−xB​(14)−B​(10)𝐵14𝑥𝐵14𝐵10\frac{B(14)-x}{B(14)-B(10)}. I.e., the situation described in Figure 1(a) happens with probability q2​(1−q)3​B​(14)−xB​(14)−B​(10)superscript𝑞2superscript1𝑞3𝐵14𝑥𝐵14𝐵10q^{2}(1-q)^{3}\frac{B(14)-x}{B(14)-B(10)}. For a complete analysis, we must also account for randomized rounding intervals [B​(10),B​(12)],[B​(10),B​(13)],[B​(10),B​(15)]𝐵10𝐵12𝐵10𝐵13𝐵10𝐵15[B(10),B(12)],[B(10),B(13)],[B(10),B(15)] and aggregate all these probabilities.

Figure 1(b) provides some insights on what the distribution induced by our quantization mechanism looks like, and seems to evidence that its shape differs from that of the Poisson Binomial Mechanism.

5.3 Theoretical analysis of RQM’s privacy guarantees

We now provide a theoretical analysis of the level of Renyi-differential privacy achieved by our single-dimensional RQM mechanism. The full proof of Theorem 5.2 is provided in Appx. B.2.

Theorem 5.2.

Let c,Δ>0, ​m∈ℕformulae-sequence𝑐Δ0 𝑚ℕc,\Delta>0,\textrm{ }m\in\mathbb{N}, and q∈(0,1)𝑞01q\in(0,1) be parameters of Algorithm 2. Consider two scalars x𝑥x and x′superscript𝑥′x^{\prime} in [−c,c]𝑐𝑐[-c,c], PQ​(x)subscript𝑃𝑄𝑥P_{Q(x)} the distribution of outputs of RQM ran on scalar x𝑥x, and PQ​(x′)subscript𝑃𝑄superscript𝑥′P_{Q(x^{\prime})} the distribution of outputs of RQM ran on scalar x′superscript𝑥′x^{\prime}. We have:

Dα(PQ​(x)||PQ​(x′))≤D∞(PQ​(x)||PQ​(x′))≤log(2(1−q)2(1+cΔ))+mlog11−q.\displaystyle D_{\alpha}(P_{Q(x)}||P_{Q(x^{\prime})})\leq D_{\infty}(P_{Q(x)}||P_{Q(x^{\prime})})\leq\log\left(2(1-q)^{2}\left(1+\frac{c}{\Delta}\right)\right)+m\log\frac{1}{1-q}. (3)

Our bound focuses on the case where α→+∞→𝛼\alpha\to+\infty, in which case (α,ϵ)𝛼italic-ϵ(\alpha,\epsilon)-Renyi differential privacy is in fact the same as (ϵ,0)italic-ϵ0(\epsilon,0)-differential privacy as per the traditional definition of DP. There, we note that the privacy level ϵ=log⁡(2​(1−q)2​(1+cΔ))+m​log⁡11−qitalic-ϵ2superscript1𝑞21𝑐Δ𝑚11𝑞\epsilon=\log\left(2(1-q)^{2}\left(1+\frac{c}{\Delta}\right)\right)+m\log\frac{1}{1-q} that we obtain increases linearly on m𝑚m, the number of quantizations level. This makes sense as a large number of quantization levels allows one to encode more information about the initial scalar x𝑥x, in turn leading to less privacy and higher ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon’s. We also note that as ΔΔ\Delta increases, ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon decreases, and we obtain more privacy; once again, this follows the intuition from Section 5.1 that when we increase the output range, we better protect the privacy of extreme values of x𝑥x that are close to c𝑐c or −c𝑐-c. As expected, when Δ=0Δ0\Delta=0, ϵ→+∞→italic-ϵ\epsilon\to+\infty and our privacy guarantees are trivial, highlighting the fact that augmenting the range of output values beyond [−c,c]𝑐𝑐[-c,c] is an unavoidable step to obtain reasonable privacy guarantees.

6 Experiments

In this section, we conduct experiments designed to complement our theoretical results and illustrate how RQM performs compared to PBM in terms of the privacy-accuracy trade-off. We first establish that RQM provides superior Renyi DP guarantees for the multiple-device scenario by numerically calculating the upper bound of Renyi divergence. Then, we employ the same parameters that yielded improved Renyi DP to demonstrate that RQM also excels in accuracy in our federated learning experiments.

6.1 Numerical Renyi privacy guarantees

In Section 5.3, we characterized the privacy guarantee of our Randomized Quantization Mechanism in the special case in which α→+∞→𝛼\alpha\to+\infty. Our privacy guarantees hold at the local level, in that it protects against a strong adversary that can see the output Q​(xi)𝑄subscript𝑥𝑖Q(x_{i}) of each device i𝑖i (but not the input data xisubscript𝑥𝑖x_{i}). A weaker but potentially interesting adversary can only see the output of the trusted, secure aggregator SecAgg111The learner only sees the output of SecAgg and is such an adversary.. In this case, assuming we have n𝑛n devices that provide scalar inputs x1,…,xnsubscript𝑥1…subscript𝑥𝑛x_{1},\ldots,x_{n}—where xisubscript𝑥𝑖x_{i} is the input of device i𝑖i—to the randomized quantization mechanism RQM222We can think of these inputs as summary statistics computed on databases D1,…,Dnsubscript𝐷1…subscript𝐷𝑛D_{1},\ldots,D_{n} before adding privacy; e.g., these could be a single coordinate of a clipped gradient., we are interested in an adversary that only sees the aggregate quantity ∑i=1nQ​(xi)superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛𝑄subscript𝑥𝑖\sum_{i=1}^{n}Q(x_{i}). Given two vectors of inputs x𝑥x and x′superscript𝑥′x^{\prime} that only differ in the input xisubscript𝑥𝑖x_{i} of a single device i𝑖i, we obtain (α,ϵ)𝛼italic-ϵ(\alpha,\epsilon)-Renyi differential privacy with

ϵ≜Dα(P∑i=1nQ​(xi)||P∑i=1nQ​(xi′)),\epsilon\triangleq D_{\alpha}\left(P_{\sum_{i=1}^{n}Q(x_{i})}||P_{\sum_{i=1}^{n}Q(x_{i}^{\prime})}\right),

as studied by Chen et al., (2022).

We use Equation (5.1) to numerically compute and plot this Renyi divergence for finite α𝛼\alpha and for n≥1𝑛1n\geq 1 in Figure 2. We compare it to the Renyi divergence of the Poisson Binomial Mechanism of Chen et al., (2022); we note that we do not compare to the upper bound provided by Chen et al., (2022) that may not be tight, but instead to the actual Renyi divergence computed numerically and exactly. In both cases, we plot the worst-case (over x𝑥x, x′superscript𝑥′x^{\prime}) Renyi divergence, which is maximized when all xisubscript𝑥𝑖x_{i}’s are either −c𝑐-c or c𝑐c333This is because (P,Q)→Dα(P||Q)(P,Q)\rightarrow D_{\alpha}(P||Q) is quasi-convex (Van Erven and Harremos,, 2014); to do so, we generate x𝑥x and x′superscript𝑥′x^{\prime} by taking x1=c,x1′=−cformulae-sequencesubscript𝑥1𝑐superscriptsubscript𝑥1′𝑐x_{1}=c,x_{1}^{\prime}=-c and randomly assigning a value of either c𝑐c or −c𝑐-c to x2,⋯,xnsubscript𝑥2⋯subscript𝑥𝑛x_{2},\cdots,x_{n}.

We fix the number of discrete levels m𝑚m as 16 for both RQM and PBM to compare privacy guarantees between the two algorithms at equal communication complexity. We set the value c𝑐c to be 1.51.51.5444Our mechanism is in fact scale-invariant for DP guarantees, and the choice of c𝑐c itself does not matter at a given constant ratio between ΔΔ\Delta and c𝑐c.. Figure 2 is then obtained using the following parameters: θ=0.25𝜃0.25\theta=0.25 for the hyperparameter of PBM555See Algorithm 2 in Chen et al., (2022) for a description of the parameters.—we provide additional experiments comparing our results to PBM with different values of θ∈[0,0.4]𝜃00.4\theta\in[0,0.4] in Appx. D—and Δ=cΔ𝑐\Delta=c with a corresponding fine-tuned q=0.42𝑞0.42q=0.42 for RQM. The left picture fixes α=2𝛼2\alpha=2 and compares the Renyi divergences of PBM and RQM when n𝑛n increases. At the same time, the Renyi divergences seem to converge to similar values for n→+∞→𝑛n\to+\infty, and we note that our framework performs better for finite values of n𝑛n, with a noticeably increasing performance gap as the number of user devices n𝑛n becomes smaller. The right picture fixes n=1𝑛1n=1, then n=40𝑛40n=40, and compares the Renyi divergence of PBM and RQM for a large range of α∈[0,1000]𝛼01000\alpha\in[0,1000]; we see significant disparities in the levels of Renyi privacy guaranteed by PBM and RQM, with RQM vastly outperforming (i.e., guaranteeing a lower Renyi divergence hence a better privacy guarantee than) PBM, with the gap in privacy guarantees increasing as α→+∞→𝛼\alpha\to+\infty.

6.2 Federated Learning experiments

In this section, we expand our experiments to provide insights beyond the privacy guarantees of the Randomized Quantization Mechanism itself, and to take into account how RQM integrates with the rest of the federated learning framework described in Section 4. We implement multi-dimensional RQM within the federated DP-SGD algorithm described in Algorithm 1).

We evaluate the privacy-accuracy trade-off of our algorithms against the current leading approach, the Poisson Binomial Mechanism (Chen et al.,, 2022), and an ideal noise-free clipped SGD benchmark that does not provide any differential privacy guarantee. The classification task for our federated learning experiment is performed on the EMNIST dataset (Cohen et al.,, 2017). The experimental setup details are provided in Appx. C.

Hyperparameter choice.

We adhere to the same hyperparameters for our FL experiments as those of Section 6.1: m=16𝑚16m=16, θ=0.25𝜃0.25\theta=0.25 for PBM, Δ=c,q=0.42formulae-sequenceΔ𝑐𝑞0.42\Delta=c,q=0.42 for RQM. To highlight the flexibility of the choice of hyperparameters for RQM (Section 5.1.1), we also plot results of two more pairs (Δ,q)=(2​c,0.57)Δ𝑞2𝑐0.57(\Delta,q)=(2c,0.57) and (Δ,q)=(0.66​c,0.33)Δ𝑞0.66𝑐0.33(\Delta,q)=(0.66c,0.33). For clipping threshold c𝑐c, we choose 2.9731×10−52.9731superscript1052.9731\times 10^{-5}.

Experimental results

The left and middle plots in Figure 3 clearly demonstrate that all three RQMs with different hyperparameter pairs show improved performance (in terms of loss and accuracy) on the EMNIST dataset than PBM. Among three RQMs, (Δ,q)=(0.66​c,0.33)Δ𝑞0.66𝑐0.33(\Delta,q)=(0.66c,0.33) achieves the best accuracy. The performance of our three RQMs are still worse than noise-free clipped SGD: this is unavoidable because noise-free clipped SGD only focus on accuracy without providing any privacy guarantees, and is an ideal, impossible-to-achieve benchmark with privacy.

The right plot in Figure 3 replicates experiment of Section 6.1 that were aimed at showcasing the privacy level achieved by RQM compared to PBM. The figure shows that the improved accuracy of the three RQMs compared to PBM in the left and middle figures does not come at the cost of privacy. In fact, the three plots together demonstrate that all three instantiations of RQM provide both better performance and better Renyi DP guarantees than PBM. I.e., in our experiments, RQM improves the privacy-accuracy trade-off of federated differentially private stochastic gradient descent compared to the current state of the art.

Appendix A Discussion

In conclusion, this paper introduces a novel algorithm, the Randomized Quantization Mechanism (RQM). The RQM achieves privacy through a two-tiered process of randomization, which includes (1) the random subsampling of viable quantization levels, and (2) the application of a randomized rounding process with these subsampled discrete levels. We have theoretically demonstrated the Renyi differential privacy guarantees of RQM for a single end-user device and provided empirical evidence of its superior performance in the privacy-accuracy trade-off compared to the state-of-the-art Poisson Binomial Mechanism (PBM). In the future, it would be worthwhile to further examine the Renyi DP guarantees of RQM for multiple-device scenarios and the case of multi-dimensional RQM from a theoretical standpoint. Furthermore, increasing the flexibility of RQM hyperparameters by assigning unique probability values qisubscript𝑞𝑖q_{i} to each i𝑖i-th discrete level presents an intriguing avenue for further enhancing the privacy-accuracy trade-off.

Appendix B Missing proofs

B.1 Proof of Lemma 5.1

In Lemma 5.1, j𝑗j is defined as x∈[B​(j),B​(j+1))𝑥𝐵𝑗𝐵𝑗1x\in[B(j),B(j+1)). We divide the range of i𝑖i into four cases-0<i≤j0𝑖𝑗0<i\leq j, i=0𝑖0i=0, j+1≤i<m−1𝑗1𝑖𝑚1j+1\leq i<m-1, i=m−1𝑖𝑚1i=m-1- and compute the discrete probability Pr​(Q​(x)=i)Pr𝑄𝑥𝑖\text{Pr}(Q(x)=i) for each case. The core proof idea of Lemma 5.1 is centered on evaluating the probability of each potential interval that can be used for randomized rounding for x𝑥x. Subsequently, the probability that Q​(x)=i𝑄𝑥𝑖Q(x)=i arises due to randomized rounding within a given interval is computed. Thus, when i≤j𝑖𝑗i\leq j and k≥j+1𝑘𝑗1k\geq j+1, we define the event Eisubscript𝐸𝑖E_{i} and Fksubscript𝐹𝑘F_{k} as below to use this notation for calculating the probability of each potential interval that can be used for the randomized rounding step in Algorithm 2.

Eisubscript𝐸𝑖\displaystyle E_{i} : the event of ​i​-th discrete level being used for randomized rounding:absent the event of 𝑖-th discrete level being used for randomized rounding\displaystyle:\text{ the event of }i\text{-th discrete level being used for randomized rounding}
Fksubscript𝐹𝑘\displaystyle F_{k} : the event of ​k​-th discrete level being used for randomized rounding:absent the event of 𝑘-th discrete level being used for randomized rounding\displaystyle:\text{ the event of }k\text{-th discrete level being used for randomized rounding} (4)

From the above definition of two events, Ei∩Fksubscript𝐸𝑖subscript𝐹𝑘E_{i}\cap F_{k} indicates an event of the interval [B​(i),B​(k)]𝐵𝑖𝐵𝑘[B(i),B(k)] being used for randomized rounding. In this event, this also means ij∗=isubscript𝑖superscript𝑗𝑖i_{j^{*}}=i and ij∗+1=ksubscript𝑖superscript𝑗1𝑘i_{j^{*}+1}=k in Algorithm 2. Now, let’s deep dive into how we can exactly calculate Pr​(Q​(x)=i)Pr𝑄𝑥𝑖\text{Pr}(Q(x)=i) for each case of four ranges.

(I) 0<i≤j0𝑖𝑗0<i\leq j:

First, Let us consider the case when 0<i≤j0𝑖𝑗0<i\leq j. Similar to the logic in Section 5.2, to have Q​(x)=i𝑄𝑥𝑖Q(x)=i, the i𝑖i-th discrete level must always be chosen while the (i+1)𝑖1(i+1)-th, ⋯⋯\cdots, j𝑗j-th discrete levels must not be chosen by the sub-sampling step of our algorithm. The probability of this happening is q​(1−q)j−i𝑞superscript1𝑞𝑗𝑖q(1-q)^{j-i}. Thus, we can use the definition of the event Eisubscript𝐸𝑖E_{i} in (B.1) for this case.

Pr(Ei)=Pr(i: chosen, (i+1,⋯,j): not chosen)=q(1−q)j−i\displaystyle\text{Pr}(E_{i})=\text{Pr}(i:\text{ chosen},\text{ }(i+1,\cdots,j):\text{ not chosen})=q(1-q)^{j-i} (5)

Let us denote k𝑘k as an index of the next quantization level bigger than x𝑥x. The possible k𝑘ks are j+1,⋯,m−1𝑗1⋯𝑚1j+1,\cdots,m-1. When k∈[j+1,m−2]𝑘𝑗1𝑚2k\in[j+1,m-2], the probability of the next quantization level bigger than x𝑥x being the k𝑘k-th level is similarly given by q​(1−q)k−j−1𝑞superscript1𝑞𝑘𝑗1q(1-q)^{k-j-1}. Thus, we can use the definition of the event Fksubscript𝐹𝑘F_{k} in (B.1) for this case.

Pr(Fk)=Pr(k: chosen, (j+1,⋯,k−1): not chosen)=q(1−q)k−j−1\displaystyle\text{Pr}(F_{k})=\text{Pr}(k:\text{ chosen},\text{ }(j+1,\cdots,k-1):\text{ not chosen})=q(1-q)^{k-j-1} (6)

Then, the likelihood of x𝑥x transitioning to the i𝑖i-th discrete level due to the randomized rounding between i𝑖i-th and k𝑘k-th levels is B​(k)−xB​(k)−B​(i)𝐵𝑘𝑥𝐵𝑘𝐵𝑖\frac{B(k)-x}{B(k)-B(i)}. This means

Pr​(Q​(x)=i|Ei∩Fk)=B​(k)−xB​(k)−B​(i)Pr𝑄𝑥conditional𝑖subscript𝐸𝑖subscript𝐹𝑘𝐵𝑘𝑥𝐵𝑘𝐵𝑖\displaystyle\text{Pr}(Q(x)=i|E_{i}\cap F_{k})=\frac{B(k)-x}{B(k)-B(i)} (7)

Therefore, for k∈[j+1,m−2]𝑘𝑗1𝑚2k\in[j+1,m-2], by combining (5), (6), (7), we get

Pr​((Q​(x)=i)∩Ei∩Fk)Pr𝑄𝑥𝑖subscript𝐸𝑖subscript𝐹𝑘\displaystyle\text{Pr}((Q(x)=i)\cap E_{i}\cap F_{k})
=\displaystyle= Pr​(Ei∩Fk)⋅Pr​(Q​(x)=i|Ei∩Fk)⋅Prsubscript𝐸𝑖subscript𝐹𝑘Pr𝑄𝑥conditional𝑖subscript𝐸𝑖subscript𝐹𝑘\displaystyle\text{Pr}(E_{i}\cap F_{k})\cdot\text{Pr}(Q(x)=i|E_{i}\cap F_{k})
=\displaystyle= Pr(Ei)⋅Pr(Fk)⋅Pr(Q(x)=i|Ei∩Fk) (∵ Ei,Fk: independent)\displaystyle\text{Pr}(E_{i})\cdot\text{Pr}(F_{k})\cdot\text{Pr}(Q(x)=i|E_{i}\cap F_{k})\text{ }(\because\text{ }E_{i},F_{k}:\text{ independent})
=\displaystyle= q​(1−q)j−i⋅q​(1−q)k−j−1⋅B​(k)−xB​(k)−B​(i)⋅⋅𝑞superscript1𝑞𝑗𝑖𝑞superscript1𝑞𝑘𝑗1𝐵𝑘𝑥𝐵𝑘𝐵𝑖\displaystyle q(1-q)^{j-i}\cdot q(1-q)^{k-j-1}\cdot\frac{B(k)-x}{B(k)-B(i)} (8)

We can perform a similar computation for k=m−1𝑘𝑚1k=m-1. However, the probability of event Fm−1subscript𝐹𝑚1F_{m-1} is different from that of Equation (6) because the (m−1)𝑚1(m-1)-th level is always chosen by Algorithm 2. Thus, we have

Pr(Fm−1)=Pr(m−1: chosen, (j+1,⋯,m−2): not chosen)=(1−q)m−j−2\displaystyle\text{Pr}(F_{m-1})=\text{Pr}(m-1:\text{ chosen},\text{ }(j+1,\cdots,m-2):\text{ not chosen})=(1-q)^{m-j-2} (9)

Therefore, for k=m−1𝑘𝑚1k=m-1, by combining Equations (5), (9), and (7), we obtain

Pr​((Q​(x)=i)∩Ei∩Fm−1)Pr𝑄𝑥𝑖subscript𝐸𝑖subscript𝐹𝑚1\displaystyle\text{Pr}((Q(x)=i)\cap E_{i}\cap F_{m-1})
=\displaystyle= Pr​(Ei∩Fm−1)⋅Pr​(Q​(x)=i|Ei∩Fm−1)⋅Prsubscript𝐸𝑖subscript𝐹𝑚1Pr𝑄𝑥conditional𝑖subscript𝐸𝑖subscript𝐹𝑚1\displaystyle\text{Pr}(E_{i}\cap F_{m-1})\cdot\text{Pr}(Q(x)=i|E_{i}\cap F_{m-1})
=\displaystyle= Pr​(Ei)⋅Pr​(Fm−1)⋅Pr​(Q​(x)=i|Ei∩Fm−1)​⋅⋅Prsubscript𝐸𝑖Prsubscript𝐹𝑚1Pr𝑄𝑥conditional𝑖subscript𝐸𝑖subscript𝐹𝑚1\displaystyle\text{Pr}(E_{i})\cdot\text{Pr}(F_{m-1})\cdot\text{Pr}(Q(x)=i|E_{i}\cap F_{m-1})\text{ }
=\displaystyle= q​(1−q)j−i⋅(1−q)m−j−2⋅B​(m−1)−xB​(m−1)−B​(i)⋅𝑞superscript1𝑞𝑗𝑖superscript1𝑞𝑚𝑗2𝐵𝑚1𝑥𝐵𝑚1𝐵𝑖\displaystyle q(1-q)^{j-i}\cdot(1-q)^{m-j-2}\cdot\frac{B(m-1)-x}{B(m-1)-B(i)} (10)

Finally, by combining Equations (B.1) and (B.1), we get

Pr​(Q​(x)=i)Pr𝑄𝑥𝑖\displaystyle\text{Pr}(Q(x)=i)
=\displaystyle= ∑k=j+1m−1Pr​((Q​(x)=i)∩Ei∩Fk)superscriptsubscript𝑘𝑗1𝑚1Pr𝑄𝑥𝑖subscript𝐸𝑖subscript𝐹𝑘\displaystyle\sum_{k=j+1}^{m-1}\text{Pr}((Q(x)=i)\cap E_{i}\cap F_{k})
=\displaystyle= q​(1−q)j−i​((1−q)m−j−2​B​(m−1)−xB​(m−1)−B​(i)+∑k=j+1m−2q​(1−q)k−j−1​B​(k)−xB​(k)−B​(i))𝑞superscript1𝑞𝑗𝑖superscript1𝑞𝑚𝑗2𝐵𝑚1𝑥𝐵𝑚1𝐵𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑘𝑗1𝑚2𝑞superscript1𝑞𝑘𝑗1𝐵𝑘𝑥𝐵𝑘𝐵𝑖\displaystyle q(1-q)^{j-i}\Big{(}(1-q)^{m-j-2}\frac{B(m-1)-x}{B(m-1)-B(i)}+\sum\limits_{k=j+1}^{m-2}q(1-q)^{k-j-1}\frac{B(k)-x}{B(k)-B(i)}\Big{)} (11)

(II) i=0𝑖0i=0:

We can compute Pr​(Q​(x)=0)Pr𝑄𝑥0\text{Pr}(Q(x)=0) in a similar way as in case (I). However, the probability of event E0subscript𝐸0E_{0} is different from that of Equation (5) because the 00-th level is always chosen by Algorithm 2. Thus, we have

Pr(E0)=Pr(0: chosen, (1,⋯,j): not chosen)=(1−q)j\displaystyle\text{Pr}(E_{0})=\text{Pr}(0:\text{ chosen},\text{ }(1,\cdots,j):\text{ not chosen})=(1-q)^{j} (12)

Therefore, in (B.1), by substituting Eisubscript𝐸𝑖E_{i} into E0subscript𝐸0E_{0}, we get

Pr​(Q​(x)=0)Pr𝑄𝑥0\displaystyle\text{Pr}(Q(x)=0)
=\displaystyle= ∑k=j+1m−1Pr​((Q​(x)=0)∩E0∩Fk)superscriptsubscript𝑘𝑗1𝑚1Pr𝑄𝑥0subscript𝐸0subscript𝐹𝑘\displaystyle\sum_{k=j+1}^{m-1}\text{Pr}((Q(x)=0)\cap E_{0}\cap F_{k})
=\displaystyle= (1−q)j​((1−q)m−j−2​B​(m−1)−xB​(m−1)−B​(0)+∑k=j+1m−2q​(1−q)k−j−1​B​(k)−xB​(k)−B​(0))superscript1𝑞𝑗superscript1𝑞𝑚𝑗2𝐵𝑚1𝑥𝐵𝑚1𝐵0superscriptsubscript𝑘𝑗1𝑚2𝑞superscript1𝑞𝑘𝑗1𝐵𝑘𝑥𝐵𝑘𝐵0\displaystyle(1-q)^{j}\Big{(}(1-q)^{m-j-2}\frac{B(m-1)-x}{B(m-1)-B(0)}+\sum\limits_{k=j+1}^{m-2}q(1-q)^{k-j-1}\frac{B(k)-x}{B(k)-B(0)}\Big{)} (13)

(III) j+1≤i<m−1𝑗1𝑖𝑚1j+1\leq i<m-1:

For i𝑖i within this range, we can similarly compute Pr​(Q​(x)=i)Pr𝑄𝑥𝑖\text{Pr}(Q(x)=i) as in (I). To obtain Q​(x)=i𝑄𝑥𝑖Q(x)=i, the i𝑖i-th discrete level must always be chosen while the (j+1)𝑗1(j+1)-th, ⋯⋯\cdots, (i−1)𝑖1(i-1)-th discrete levels must not be chosen by the sub-sampling step of our algorithm. Thus, since i≥j+1𝑖𝑗1i\geq j+1, the probability of i𝑖i-th discrete level being used for randomized rounding can be expressed by using Fisubscript𝐹𝑖F_{i} (refer to (6)).

Pr(Fi)=Pr(i: chosen, (j+1,⋯,i−1): not chosen)=q(1−q)i−j−1\displaystyle\text{Pr}(F_{i})=\text{Pr}(i:\text{ chosen},\text{ }(j+1,\cdots,i-1):\text{ not chosen})=q(1-q)^{i-j-1} (14)

Let us denote k𝑘k as an index of the just previous level less than x𝑥x. The possible k𝑘k’s are 0,⋯,j0⋯𝑗0,\cdots,j. Then, for k∈[1,j]𝑘1𝑗k\in[1,j], the probability of the k𝑘k-th discrete level being used for randomized rounding can be represented by utilizing Eksubscript𝐸𝑘E_{k} (refer to (5)).

Pr(Ek)=Pr(k: chosen, (k+1,⋯,j): not chosen)=q(1−q)j−k\displaystyle\text{Pr}(E_{k})=\text{Pr}(k:\text{ chosen},\text{ }(k+1,\cdots,j):\text{ not chosen})=q(1-q)^{j-k} (15)

Then, the likelihood of x𝑥x transitioning to the i𝑖i-th discrete level due to the randomized rounding between k𝑘k-th and i𝑖i-th levels is x−B​(k)B​(i)−B​(k)𝑥𝐵𝑘𝐵𝑖𝐵𝑘\frac{x-B(k)}{B(i)-B(k)}. This means

Pr​(Q​(x)=i|Ek∩Fi)=x−B​(k)B​(i)−B​(k)Pr𝑄𝑥conditional𝑖subscript𝐸𝑘subscript𝐹𝑖𝑥𝐵𝑘𝐵𝑖𝐵𝑘\displaystyle\text{Pr}(Q(x)=i|E_{k}\cap F_{i})=\frac{x-B(k)}{B(i)-B(k)} (16)

Therefore, for k∈[1,j]𝑘1𝑗k\in[1,j], by combining (14), (15), (16), we get

Pr​((Q​(x)=i)∩Ek∩Fi)Pr𝑄𝑥𝑖subscript𝐸𝑘subscript𝐹𝑖\displaystyle\text{Pr}((Q(x)=i)\cap E_{k}\cap F_{i})
=\displaystyle= Pr​(Fi)⋅Pr​(Ek)⋅Pr​(Q​(x)=i|Ek∩Fi)​⋅⋅Prsubscript𝐹𝑖Prsubscript𝐸𝑘Pr𝑄𝑥conditional𝑖subscript𝐸𝑘subscript𝐹𝑖\displaystyle\text{Pr}(F_{i})\cdot\text{Pr}(E_{k})\cdot\text{Pr}(Q(x)=i|E_{k}\cap F_{i})\text{ }
=\displaystyle= q​(1−q)i−j−1⋅q​(1−q)j−k⋅x−B​(k)B​(i)−B​(k)⋅⋅𝑞superscript1𝑞𝑖𝑗1𝑞superscript1𝑞𝑗𝑘𝑥𝐵𝑘𝐵𝑖𝐵𝑘\displaystyle q(1-q)^{i-j-1}\cdot q(1-q)^{j-k}\cdot\frac{x-B(k)}{B(i)-B(k)} (17)

We can similarly calculate for k=0𝑘0k=0 by using (12).

Pr​((Q​(x)=i)∩E0∩Fi)Pr𝑄𝑥𝑖subscript𝐸0subscript𝐹𝑖\displaystyle\text{Pr}((Q(x)=i)\cap E_{0}\cap F_{i})
=\displaystyle= Pr​(Fi)⋅Pr​(E0)⋅Pr​(Q​(x)=i|E0∩Fi)​⋅⋅Prsubscript𝐹𝑖Prsubscript𝐸0Pr𝑄𝑥conditional𝑖subscript𝐸0subscript𝐹𝑖\displaystyle\text{Pr}(F_{i})\cdot\text{Pr}(E_{0})\cdot\text{Pr}(Q(x)=i|E_{0}\cap F_{i})\text{ }
=\displaystyle= q​(1−q)i−j−1⋅(1−q)j⋅x−B​(0)B​(i)−B​(0)⋅𝑞superscript1𝑞𝑖𝑗1superscript1𝑞𝑗𝑥𝐵0𝐵𝑖𝐵0\displaystyle q(1-q)^{i-j-1}\cdot(1-q)^{j}\cdot\frac{x-B(0)}{B(i)-B(0)} (18)

Finally, by combining (B.1) and (B.1)

Pr​(Q​(x)=i)Pr𝑄𝑥𝑖\displaystyle\text{Pr}(Q(x)=i)
=\displaystyle= ∑k=0jPr​((Q​(x)=i)∩Ek∩Fi)superscriptsubscript𝑘0𝑗Pr𝑄𝑥𝑖subscript𝐸𝑘subscript𝐹𝑖\displaystyle\sum_{k=0}^{j}\text{Pr}((Q(x)=i)\cap E_{k}\cap F_{i})
=\displaystyle= q​(1−q)i−j−1​((1−q)j​x−B​(0)B​(i)−B​(0)+∑k=1jq​(1−q)j−k​x−B​(k)B​(i)−B​(k))𝑞superscript1𝑞𝑖𝑗1superscript1𝑞𝑗𝑥𝐵0𝐵𝑖𝐵0superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑗𝑞superscript1𝑞𝑗𝑘𝑥𝐵𝑘𝐵𝑖𝐵𝑘\displaystyle q(1-q)^{i-j-1}\Big{(}(1-q)^{j}\frac{x-B(0)}{B(i)-B(0)}+\sum\limits_{k=1}^{j}q(1-q)^{j-k}\frac{x-B(k)}{B(i)-B(k)}\Big{)} (19)

(IV) i=m−1𝑖𝑚1i=m-1:

We can calculate Pr​(Q​(x)=m−1)Pr𝑄𝑥𝑚1\text{Pr}(Q(x)=m-1) in a similar way compared to case (III). However, the (m−1𝑚1m-1)-th level should be always chosen by Algorithm 2, we rely on Equation (9) rather than Equation (14). We obtain:

Pr​(Q​(x)=m−1)Pr𝑄𝑥𝑚1\displaystyle\text{Pr}(Q(x)=m-1)
=\displaystyle= ∑k=0jPr​((Q​(x)=m−1)∩Ek∩Fm−1)superscriptsubscript𝑘0𝑗Pr𝑄𝑥𝑚1subscript𝐸𝑘subscript𝐹𝑚1\displaystyle\sum_{k=0}^{j}\text{Pr}((Q(x)=m-1)\cap E_{k}\cap F_{m-1})
=\displaystyle= (1−q)m−j−2​((1−q)j​x−B​(0)B​(m−1)−B​(0)+∑k=1jq​(1−q)j−k​x−B​(k)B​(m−1)−B​(k))superscript1𝑞𝑚𝑗2superscript1𝑞𝑗𝑥𝐵0𝐵𝑚1𝐵0superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑗𝑞superscript1𝑞𝑗𝑘𝑥𝐵𝑘𝐵𝑚1𝐵𝑘\displaystyle(1-q)^{m-j-2}\Big{(}(1-q)^{j}\frac{x-B(0)}{B(m-1)-B(0)}+\sum\limits_{k=1}^{j}q(1-q)^{j-k}\frac{x-B(k)}{B(m-1)-B(k)}\Big{)} (20)

Therefore, we finally get Equation (5.1) of Lemma 5.1 from combining cases (I), (II), (III), and (IV).

B.2 Proof of Theorem 5.2

We use Lemma 3.4 to find an upper bound on Dα(PQ​(x)||PQ​(x′))D_{\alpha}(P_{Q(x)}||P_{Q(x^{\prime})}).

Dα(PQ​(x)||PQ​(x′))\displaystyle D_{\alpha}(P_{Q(x)}||P_{Q(x^{\prime})}) ≤D∞(PQ​(x)||PQ​(x′))\displaystyle\leq D_{\infty}(P_{Q(x)}||P_{Q(x^{\prime})})
≤D∞(PQ​(c)||PQ​(−c))\displaystyle\leq D_{\infty}(P_{Q(c)}||P_{Q(-c)})
=supi∈{0,1,⋯,m−1}log⁡(P​(Q​(c)=i)P​(Q​(−c)=i))absentsubscriptsupremum𝑖01⋯𝑚1𝑃𝑄𝑐𝑖𝑃𝑄𝑐𝑖\displaystyle=\sup_{i\in\{0,1,\cdots,m-1\}}\log\Big{(}\frac{P(Q(c)=i)}{P(Q(-c)=i)}\Big{)}

The second inequality comes from the fact that the Renyi divergence is maximized at extreme points: this is because (P,Q)→Dα(P||Q)(P,Q)\rightarrow D_{\alpha}(P||Q) is quasi-convex as observed in (Van Erven and Harremos,, 2014). We establish a value for j𝑗j that makes it so that −c𝑐-c falls within the range of values between B​(j)𝐵𝑗B(j) and B​(j+1)𝐵𝑗1B(j+1). Since P​(Q​(c)=i)≤1𝑃𝑄𝑐𝑖1P(Q(c)=i)\leq 1 and arg⁡mini⁡P​(Q​(−c)=i)=m−1subscript𝑖𝑃𝑄𝑐𝑖𝑚1\arg\min_{i}P(Q(-c)=i)=m-1, we obtain

Dα(PQ​(x)||PQ​(x′))\displaystyle D_{\alpha}(P_{Q(x)}||P_{Q(x^{\prime})}) ≤supi∈{0,1,⋯,m−1}log⁡(P​(Q​(c)=i)P​(Q​(−c)=i))absentsubscriptsupremum𝑖01⋯𝑚1𝑃𝑄𝑐𝑖𝑃𝑄𝑐𝑖\displaystyle\leq\sup_{i\in\{0,1,\cdots,m-1\}}\log\Big{(}\frac{P(Q(c)=i)}{P(Q(-c)=i)}\Big{)}
≤log⁡(1P​(Q​(−c)=m−1))absent1𝑃𝑄𝑐𝑚1\displaystyle\leq\log\Big{(}\frac{1}{P(Q(-c)=m-1)}\Big{)}
=log⁡(1(1−q)m−2⋅−c−B​(0)B​(m−1)−B​(0)+∑k=1jq​(1−q)m−2−k⋅−c−B​(k)B​(m−1)−B​(k))absent1⋅superscript1𝑞𝑚2𝑐𝐵0𝐵𝑚1𝐵0superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑗⋅𝑞superscript1𝑞𝑚2𝑘𝑐𝐵𝑘𝐵𝑚1𝐵𝑘\displaystyle=\log\bigg{(}\frac{1}{(1-q)^{m-2}\cdot\frac{-c-B(0)}{B(m-1)-B(0)}+\sum\limits_{k=1}^{j}q(1-q)^{m-2-k}\cdot\frac{-c-B(k)}{B(m-1)-B(k)}}\bigg{)}
=log⁡(1(1−q)m−2⋅Δ2​c+2​Δ+∑k=1jq​(1−q)m−2−k⋅−c−B​(k)c+Δ−B​(k))absent1⋅superscript1𝑞𝑚2Δ2𝑐2Δsuperscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑗⋅𝑞superscript1𝑞𝑚2𝑘𝑐𝐵𝑘𝑐Δ𝐵𝑘\displaystyle=\log\bigg{(}\frac{1}{(1-q)^{m-2}\cdot\frac{\Delta}{2c+2\Delta}+\sum\limits_{k=1}^{j}q(1-q)^{m-2-k}\cdot\frac{-c-B(k)}{c+\Delta-B(k)}}\bigg{)}
≤log⁡1(1−q)m−2⋅Δ2​c+2​Δabsent1⋅superscript1𝑞𝑚2Δ2𝑐2Δ\displaystyle\leq\log\frac{1}{(1-q)^{m-2}\cdot\frac{\Delta}{2c+2\Delta}}
=log⁡(2​(1−q)2​(c+Δ)Δ)+m​log⁡11−qabsent2superscript1𝑞2𝑐ΔΔ𝑚11𝑞\displaystyle=\log\left(\frac{2(1-q)^{2}(c+\Delta)}{\Delta}\right)+m\log\frac{1}{1-q}

To go from the second to the third line, we used Lemma 5.1.

Appendix C Experimental setup details

Implementation environment.

We adopt the same implementation setup as outlined in Chen et al., (2022). To implement our algorithm, we utilize TensorFlow (Abadi et al.,, 2015) and the TensorFlow Federated (TFF) library. Our computational resources include 2 NVIDIA RTX A5000 GPUs. We simulate a federated learning scenario involving a total of 3,40034003,400 local devices, with n=40𝑛40n=40 local devices participating in each round. The total number of communication rounds is set to 2,00020002,000.

Dataset & training model.

We perform image classification on the EMNIST dataset, which is comprised of 62 classes. We employ a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) as the learning model for our training purposes.

Appendix D Additional experimental results

In Section 6, we opted for θ=0.25𝜃0.25\theta=0.25 as a hyperparameter for PBM and identified the pairs (Δ,q)Δ𝑞(\Delta,q) - hyperparameters for RQM - that yielded a superior privacy-accuracy trade-off. Here, in this section, we extend our investigation by conducting additional experiments with a range of θ𝜃\theta values within the [0,0.4]00.4[0,0.4] interval, seeking to underscore the superiority of RQM in achieving a better privacy-accuracy trade-off compared to PBM across a wider range of θ𝜃\theta values considered by Chen et al., (2022). For these subsequent trials, we choose θ=0.15𝜃0.15\theta=0.15 and θ=0.35𝜃0.35\theta=0.35.

D.1 Additional DP experiments

In line with the experimental protocol detailed in Section 6.1, we conduct additional trials using differing θ𝜃\theta values: θ=0.15𝜃0.15\theta=0.15 and θ=0.35𝜃0.35\theta=0.35. Consistent with the results reported in 6.1, these extended trials again demonstrate RQM’s superior performance, reflected in its lower Renyi divergence, and thus enhanced privacy guarantee when compared with PBM.

Additional experiment with θ=0.15𝜃0.15\theta=0.15.

We choose (Δ,q)=(2.33​c,0.42)Δ𝑞2.33𝑐0.42(\Delta,q)=(2.33c,0.42) for RQM to compare with PBM with θ=0.15𝜃0.15\theta=0.15. The results of this experiment can be found in Figure 4.

Additional experiment with θ=0.35𝜃0.35\theta=0.35.

We choose (Δ,q)=(0.429​c,0.49)Δ𝑞0.429𝑐0.49(\Delta,q)=(0.429c,0.49) for RQM to compare with PBM with θ=0.35𝜃0.35\theta=0.35. The results of this experiment can be found in Figure 5.

D.2 Additional FL experiments

We follow the same FL experimental setup as in Section 6.2. For the choice of hyperparameters, we use the same hyperparameters for the additional FL experiments as those of Appx. D.1. We also plot results for two more (Δ,q)Δ𝑞(\Delta,q) pairs, for both θ𝜃\theta values θ=0.15𝜃0.15\theta=0.15 and θ=0.35𝜃0.35\theta=0.35. Echoing the findings of Section 6.2, our additional analysis shows that, for the above values of θ𝜃\theta, all three instantiations of RQM consistently outperform PBM in terms of both performance (measured both in terms of loss and accuracy) and Renyi DP guarantees.

Additional experiment with θ=0.15𝜃0.15\theta=0.15.
